column3: Adversary ability to perform crypto operations
column4: Adversary would have the ability to perform signing and cryptographic operations that would permit the adversary to masquerade as a legitimate authorized user and perform operations against NFs.

column2: Consume data allocation to deny or degrade service
column3: Sustained degraded communication until additional data is purchased.
column4: Sustained degraded communication until additional data is purchased.

column3: Information of what other services are provided by a given MNO
SUPI is available to the adversary
AMF service will not be available to legitimate users during attack.
column4: If AMF services are down, all services for the existing UEs which use NAS layer will not be available. For example: mobility, session management (QoS etc.), PDU session set up / tear down, SMS over NAS, location management. [Section 8.2.2.1 of 23.501]
Geolocation can make electronic attack for degradation of service more effective, bidding down to defeat ID and traffic confidentiality more effective, and can expose user to physical attack.

column2: DOS a UE via fake cellular base station
column4: Communications are generally possible shortly after attacker stops transmitting. In some cases, UE might be locked down and require reboot or service provider intervention.
Allows attacker to identify UE as target of interest for geolocation, degradation of service, loss of traffic confidentiality, or physical attack.

column3: Identifier of some network nodes is known and thus can be spoofed, DOSed, etc.
User/UE data is revealed over the air interface
column4:
Control Plane: All UE signaling data may be revealed if both NAS and AS CP (RRC) algorithms are weakened.

User Plane: Subscriber (user plane) data may be revealed if AS UP algorithms are weakened.
Network flow compromise can lead to DOS, or change the traffic pattern and paths.  Adversary may change the path for network sniffing or for MiTM activity.

column4: Network flow compromise can lead to DOS, or change the traffic pattern and paths.  Adversary may change the path for network sniffing or for MiTM activity.

column4: Denial of service continues until service provider is convinced there is no fraud.

column2: Redirection of traffic via user plane network function
column4: If adversary redirects to their own server, they can access the downlink data of the subscriber, who will not be aware that the traffic is being intercepted.

A compromised image deployed in the production can lead to variety of adversarial activities depending on what capabilities were added/deleted from the image.

When home network is unusual (e.g., US home network in Afghanistan), allows attacker to identify UE as target of interest for geolocation, degradation of service, loss of traffic confidentiality, or physical attack.
